name: Shoryu-Ken
description:
Street fighter fans? Nothing new here. Just decided to use all my favorite runner cards in a deck.

Account siphon, Indexing, Makers Eye, Legwork, and same old thing -- Same old things right?

Atman's and datasuckers should work well for you for the amount of running you're doing.

I'm not sure if a third Datasucker should go iin, but stimhack is so great for a last resort.

I haven't looked at any other Ken decks on db or anywhere else. I apologize if this is copying somebody else.

Tell me your thoughts!

name: Taxations and Profits
description:
This deck circles around in Economy, from the Agendas, Operations, and the ID itself, to pay for the ICE biggies like Tollbooth, Curtain Wall, and Hadrian's Wall. Off the Grid will setup as the scoring server, or to protect J-How and Isabel. Chunk HQ and R&D from the beginning using small ICE, then replace them with big ICE using Blue Sun or Isabel, then chunk big ICE for Off the Grid. Isabel and Blue Sun also serves as removing Parasites, Knights, Femme's "virus", etc., and Amazon Industrial Zone will serve as an ICE discount.

Any thoughts? Thanks for reading!

name: Anthony & Anthony's "Special" Kid
description:
As seen on Genstealer's Twitch stream 5/22/14. http://www.twitch.tv/genestealers

15-1!

name: Generic NBN
Blue Sun: High Threat Response
description: Why should you ever care about Bad Publicity when you have an Elizabeth Mills Reputation Engine at your disposal?

name: The Sun Rises in the East
description:
You're gonna have a lot of remote servers in this deck.

Your "scoring" server should be the only one with ICE in front of it.

The one thing to mulligan for is a Komainu or Tsurugi to throw on HQ if you suspect your opponent is playing account siphon (which is likely).

Mental Health Clinic, in addition to being free money per turn, has additional synergy with Komainu to make it more taxing.

The advantage of all the agendas being 3 advancement (sans Fetal AI) is that you can even throw a few remote servers down and the runner has to either run on all of them or potentially let you score an agenda.

The main agendas you want to ensure you're the one scoring are House of Knives and Philotic Entanglement. The other agendas it isn't really a big deal if the runner gets them.

Basically you're just gonna either flatline the runner or they'll be (rightly) afraid to run and you'll score your agendas with ease

name: Teltin v0.21 alpha
description:
Named after Mass Effect's facility where Cerberus kept Jack when she was a child. A very nasty place with some very nasty secrets. Just like this deck, hopefully.

I haven't playtested it yet, so these strategy tips might just be a load of nonsense, but hey, I tried my best.

You should play one Medical Breakthrough (MB from now on) very early game (doesn't matter if gets stolen or scored) because the Runner getting those two early points isn't that big of a deal thanks to MB's ability.

Adonis and Melange to get some cash mid-game. You probably only need one of those in play at any given time but they give you different options. Putting some taxing ICE (Pup, Rainbow and maybe Swordsman to take three or four credits out of the Runner) in front of them might even get you an economic advantage. Also, Beanstalk Royalties and Green Level Clearance are always nice, no matter when they come up. A couple of Hedge Funds to try to work around v0.1's lack of early-game economy.

The Junebugs are there to get the mind games running. A Mushin No Shin - Junebug combo at the right time can win a match.

Tori Hanzo might get played alongside Komainu but it's not a central part of the deck. Same goes for Susanoo-No-Mikoto.

The psi cards seem like a lot of fun to play with. Don't know if they'll make it into my tournament decks but they are fantastic flavour for this deck. Caprice Nisei can save your butt or act as bait. Psychic Field is just nasty. Awesome card. Took out a Cerebral Cast and added another Snare! Jinteki's good ole nasty surprise.

Well, that's about it. Enjoy.

v0.21: Thanks to Woolierwand's suggestions I got the deck down to 44 cards. Maybe I'll add some more out-of-faction stuff later but I need to play with before I do that because I'm really bad at figuring this stuff out without actually playing.

name: Taxations and Profits 2.0
description:
This deck circles around in Economy, from the Agendas, Operations, and the ID itself, to pay for the ICE biggies like Tollbooth, Curtain Wall, and Hadrian's Wall. Off the Grid will setup as the scoring server, or to protect J-How and Isabel. Chunk HQ and R&D from the beginning using small ICE, then replace them with big ICE using Blue Sun or Isabel, then chunk big ICE for Off the Grid. Isabel and Blue Sun also serves as removing Parasites, Knights, Femme's "virus", etc., and Amazon Industrial Zone will serve as an ICE discount.

*edited with -3 Isabel McGuire = +2 Adonis Campaign and +1 Off the Grid

Any thoughts? Thanks for reading!

name: Haas-Bioroid
description: Premier jeu crée. En constante amélioration !

name: Advance like there is no tomorrow
description:
The basic idea is simple, use Mushin No Shin to advance cards that may or may not kill the runner outright, then use Trick of Light to throw down and score an agenda. Reclamation Order is there in order to cycle Trick of Light and/or Mushin No Shin. While the Tennin Institute: The Secrets Within doesn't need a card that can be advanced in order to put advancement tokens on them, it is nice to use advance able ice.

My main concern right now are my agendas. I'm of a mind to swap almost all my current agendas with ones with advance requirement of 3 . This would mean that I need about 2 to 4 more card slots and I'm not sure that I have the card space.

As always, I'd appreciate any feedback

name: Kate & Dagger v4.3
description:
I like Dagger, I like Paintbrush. Let's make a deck with them!

I like all the recurring credits, so I'm adding in Cyberfeeders, using the influence that was previously used for a Corroder, which got replaced with a Battering Ram to help against stacked barriers.

Forged Activation Orders got swapped for E3-s, also because of big, multi-subroutine ICE like Heimdall and Ichi.

e3 worked well, Cyberfeeder kept me from burning cloaks on non-stealth breakers.
One tiny change that I'm making after last night is swapping one of the two SMCs for a third Test Run. I found that being able to pop a dead breaker back into the land of the living was very important in the mid-to-late game.

name: The theory of a Chaos Overmind
description:
Overmind spam more or less. I'm still not sure if this thing would work though and since I don't think that I'll have the opportunity to test this deck anytime soon, I'm hoping that someone here will be brave and try it out!:)

As always, I'd appreciate any feedback.

name: Tennin Never-Advance
description: Idea of this deck is to bluff out agendas behind gear check ice, and then score them the next turn with Tenin's ability. There's some mild fast advance and program destruction/ tax to discourage running, and a couple of SanSans will help you finish out a few games.

name: New Corp Deck
description: just a beginner deck

name: Red: Heartbreaker
Running on somebody else's money
Hard Theory
NEXT Bioroid Offensive
I wanna rock
Checkmate
description: An idea I have but havent built it yet. suggestions and tips welcome (still new at this game). what is needed?

name: Blue Sun's Zenith V0,1
description:
Just experimenting with the Blue Sun identity, but I think this list has potential.

The identity can let you reuse assets like Eve Campaign and Private Contracts to keep your Econ moving. Amazon Industrial Grid can give you similar benefits, letting you spend two to install a Hive but then gain five the following turn.

The ICE is a mix between cheap, early game ICE like Quandary, Ice Wall, Burke Bugs, and Hive, and ICE for later game like Archer and Curtain Wall. I would really like to find space to fit in other larger ICE such as Tollbooth, Hadrian's Wall, etc. as well, as I think this deck could benefit from them.

Eliza's Toybox and Amazon Industrial Grid allow for some return from your "investments."

The ICE definitely needs work, but seeing as I won't be running this deck anytime soon, there is time for improvement.

name: Bullet to the Face
description: I am new at this but I built this with the idea of tagging the runner and flatlining him primarily with meat damage. I have messed with it and tampered but it still isnt perfect. Moderately successful but am also new so as i get better, so does this deck. Any advice would be wonderful. It has won all its games, but it has been too close several times (all games meaning 4 games). I encountered Plascrete for the first time and it made things very difficult so i changed things up including changing my identity. I picked GRNDL due to how i was always ending up at 11 IP while working on this deck. I have found the 10$ SUPER useful especially if i draw restructure. I cannot decide if I want to switch vulcan coverup with profiteering. Both have had uses but I have encountered proffiteering more often during my experimentation than i have vulcan coverup when i test it out. Still working on it but any advice would be nice

name: Running on somebody else's money
Jinteki Asylum
description: Brain damage a palla

name: NEXT best thing...
description:
Okay, so this is a NEXT design list I've been tinkering with for a while. I don't think it's quite there; it needs a more elegant solution for its money problems as it stands.

I chose a NEXT design deck because I don't like traditional rush strategies. I often find that a pure rush deck tends to be so finely tuned that minor disruptions can often lead to major problems. NEXT, by contrast, can be Iced up and ready to roll turn one. It is not uncommon for this deck to end the first turn with one ice on R&D, one on HQ, two on a remote, and an agenda installed. You can then often outright score that agenda whilst the runner is still finding their feet. You should then be able to use this early advantage to stay ahead, particularly if you scored a good ABT or Mandatory Upgrades.

BREAKDOWN:

ICE: Ice is the alpha and omega of this deck, so this took a bit of getting right. If I'm trying to score an early agenda, I need the runner to be stopped dead, and I need to be able to do so without crippling my early economy. Thus, all the ice has ETR except Janus, and over 2/3 of it costs 3 or less. Thus, if I get either of the economy operations, I should be able to rez at least two bits of ice and still score a 3pt agenda next turn, more or less.

When NEXT silver comes out, it will replace Wall of Static, no questions asked. The sentry suite needs work, but there are very few that end runs cheaply. Draco is a bit too porous.

Wotan, Heimdall and Janus are all potential ABT winners.

Agendas: ABT is a beast in this deck; add another layer to your centrals, start a new remote, whatever. Yes, you will dump an agenda (at least, I usually do) occasionally, but I took JH out of the deck because it didn't happen enough to worry me. Also, this deck can often overscore Vitruvius, so it's not always totally bleak. The Mandatory Upgrades used to be Efficiency Committees, but I kept finding that I wanted to advance cards with the extra clicks. I gave it a shot, and to be honest the MU's were only slightly harder to score than the Committees. If you can score one, then you can score 8 of the remaining 10 agendas out of hand. Gila Hands Arcology is, as yet, untested, but I'm hoping it will add some much needed economy to this deck

OPERATIONS: Get money. Beanstalks used to be GLC, but I never really needed the extra card, but I frequently need the extra credit. I tried Sweeps week, but found it a bit intermittent. The only non-operation I think this deck could use is Power Shutdown, but space is so tight.

ASSETS and UPGRADES: Ash, of course is groovy. I wish I could fit a third one in... this is the only change for which I would consider dropping ICE. PCs has been Melange and Adonis in its time; still not settled on which. Melange is better burst, but too easy to trash. Adonis is passive, but can only give me a limited amount a turn. Director Haas is a card that I either discard when I see it because the time isn't right, or use to win the game. The reward is easily worth the risk if you can protect her even vaguely well for a turn or two.

HOW I PLAY: Get four bits of ice down by the end of the first turn, with some money, and an agenda behind it. Turn two, score the agenda; ABT for preference. If you think your opponent might take more than 2 turns to set up, then think about MU. If you score that early you'll almost certainly win. Beyond that, keep an eye on your money, as it will be low. I rarely needed to set up more than one remote server, unless ABT made it seem attractive.

name: Make 'em Pay V 1.2
description:
The current Jinteki Deck I am playing, undefeated on OCTGN and doing very well in my local tournaments.

Stealing my agendas costs a lot, between sticking Fetal AI and NAPD Contract behind costly ICE like Tollbooth and backed up by Caprice, plus they will need to have already run on my central servers, which sit behind ICE like Komainu, Tsurugi, Yagura, Shiro, Neural Katana to make 'em pay with their hands. Himitsu-Bako can protect Assets depending on who I'm facing. To make matters worse, the ambushes make my opponents think twice before running on any of my central servers; I'll even dare my opponents to run with Celebrity Gift. When they finally manage to steal an agenda, Punitive Counterstrike can make it hurt or even flatline them, but most of the time they just can't afford to take my agendas before I can score up for game. This list is a lot of fun, you'll find yourself daring your opponents to take risks they can't afford. I have on more than one occasion had both my copies of The Future Perfect in my archives, along with a few Shocks and Shi.Kyu's, and watched my opponents pay to just try and steal them time and again.

A note about ICE: You want a good mix of taxation and punishment without forgetting the ETR ICE. Tollbooth works wonderfully with the theme of the deck, and the Economy is strong enough to support it. RSVP works similarly, as it prevents any of your Agendas from being stolen, but if your opponent does not realize this they may continue the run anyway, potentially hitting ambushes or other nasty ICE. I have also played many games where I stick RSVP in front of Sundew in order to protect my Econ, so it really functions as a "jack-of-all-trades" ICE. Komainu, Neural Katana, and Tsurugi all hit 'em where it hurts, while Yagura and Shiro function beautifully when protecting R&D. Pup is an extra two credits for them to pay- it isn't much, but it's consistent, and without that much cost to you. I usually stick the Himitsu-Bako's in front of Remote Servers containing Sundew or early game Agendas, and move them around later if I need to. Tenma Line is a new card I'm trying out, but I have discovered it allows me to counter the odd Escher or move my ICE where I need them late game.

About Ambushes: I don't run advance ambushes, because I rarely rely on bluffing to hurt my opponent. I'll keep my Snares in my hand all game just to make it hurt when they run on HQ, or be afraid of how many their may be left in R&D. Shock! and Shi.kyu serve the same purpose, and you'll notice this deck technically runs 11 ambushes and 9 agendas. Multiaccess hurts them more than it hurts me, especially if they are face-checking any of my nastier ICE.

Let me know what you guys think, feedback is always welcome.

name: Make 'em Pay (Runner Version) V1.0
description:
I tried to take the concept from my current corp deck of never letting my opponents have any money and apply it to a runner deck. I'm not sure how well it turned out, but it was really just an experiment. Drain all their credits with Blackguard and Account Siphon, and then run places where they can't afford to defend themselves.

Just an experiment, I know the Econ is weak and my only defense against Scorched Earth combos is hoping they don't have the money to play them. Still, feedback is welcome.

name: Hard ICED Tea V1.2
description:
Shut your opponent out with an absurd amount of ICE. Use Jackson Howard to draw like crazy and don't be afraid to dump Bioroid ICE into your archives. To win with a combo, put Whirpool in front of Howler and hit them with Janus when they least expect it (for instance, you can do this even if you only have one credit). If you really want to make your opponent cry, put Whirlpool and Howler in front of a Cell Portal.

Feedback is welcome, and feel free to check out either my previous version or the version suggested by Baotus.

name: PSYCHO PSYCHO
Red Queen's Taxes
description: I've been wanting to try a deck like this ever since Reina was spoiled. I love the idea of making it incredibly expensive for the corp to rez ice, making runs much easier. Even when they do rez it, Emergency Shutdown and Kraken are there to make it even more painful.

name: SEA Source + Snare! + Scorched Earth +Punitive Counterstrike
Director Haas + Mandatory Upgrades + SanSan
Project Junebug + Mushin No Shin + Trick of Light + SanSan
Spam That Button! Fast Edition
description: Here is a mockup deck of a very fast way to go to the victory. Earn some cash, and whenever a HQ run comes in, buy as much card as possible (leave a single credit or 2). Grab the cards you want to make a good remote and go for the win.

name: Set Sail!
description:
First attempt.

Slightly slower deck with strong economy and load of silver bullets, plenty of ways to modify rig mid-run.

SET SAIL!

name: Set Sail!
description:
First attempt.

Slightly slower deck with strong economy and load of silver bullets, plenty of ways to modify rig mid-run.

SET SAIL!

name: I'M IM SPACE
Taxations and Profits 3.0
description:
This deck circles around in Economy, to pay for the ICE biggies like Tollbooth, Curtain Wall, and Hadrian's Wall. Off the Grid will setup as the scoring server, or to protect J-How and all other Assets/Upgrades. Chunk HQ and R&D from the beginning using small ICE, then replace them with big ICE using Blue Sun or Isabel, then chunk big ICE for Off the Grid. Blue Sun also serves as removing Parasites, Knights, Femme's "virus", etc., and Amazon Industrial Zone, and AI Oversight will serve as an ICE discount. J-How can also recycle Oversight AI for better economy recursion.

*edited with -3 Hostile Takeover, -3 Profiteering, -3 Project Atlas, -2 Archer, -1 Government Contracts, = + 3 Priority Requisition, +3 NAPD Contract, +3 Oversight AI, +2 Guard, +1 Amazon Industrial Zone, Any thoughts? Thanks for reading!

name: KnightKenma.o8d
